hotspots.hotspot:
Shape

The shape of apples may vary, but oranges are always round.

Browning or acidulation

Apples are subject to browning or acidulation after they are sliced, but oranges are not.

Disease tolerance

Both apple and orange trees are subject to a variety of diseases and pests.

Distribution

Both apples and oranges were spread through informal trade.

Consumption

Humans may eat all parts of an apple, but oranges are peeled before human consumption.

Pollination

Apples require cross-pollination of blossoms; usually honey bees serve as the pollinators. Oranges are self-pollinating, however, and do not require bees or other insects to pollinate the blossoms.

Varieties

More than 7,500 different varieties of apples grow in different parts of the world. At least 50 major varieties of oranges are grown in the world today.

hotspots.hotspot:
Inca Empire

The Inca Empire stretched from the center of modern Ecuador across the western half of Peru, much of Bolivia, northern Chile, and northwest Argentina in western South America.

China

China boasts one of the world's oldest civilizations. Chinese empires sprawled across river valleys, deserts, and into several mountainous regions in eastern Asia.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Influence of Geography

One of the most earthquake-prone areas on Earth is the western part of South America, including the Andes. For this reason, Inca buildings were rarely higher than one story. Other architectural challenges included building suspension bridges across deep valleys, road systems, and stair-stepped walkways up mountainsides to help humans move from place to place within the empire.

Decorative Elements

Most Inca buildings were rectangular in shape and had few design elements. Even palaces and temples were rectangular in design. Few defensive works were constructed throughout the empire, and city walls were only ornamental because the Inca faced no significant external enemies until the Spanish conquistadors arrived.

Building Materials

Timber was not often used in construction because there were few trees in the empire. Building materials were usually stone, sometimes shaped into complex polygonal shapes so finely crafted that a knife blade could not be inserted between individual stones. Adobe plastered over masonry was also used.

Source of Construction Labor

For construction labor, Inca rulers imposed a system called mita, where subjects were forced into performing work part of each year on roads, suspension bridges, palaces, and huge warehouses where food, textiles, and other items were stockpiled to be distributed by Inca administrators.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (c)DAJ/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Influence of Geography

China is located in an active earthquake zone, and southwestern China has been the scene of many significant earthquakes. The Chinese built monumental palaces, temples, and intricate canals and reservoirs in plains regions and river valleys that often flooded. Location of hostile nomadic peoples to the north dictated the construction of defensive walls and forts.

Decorative Elements

Dwellings were intricately designed and carefully maintained. Mythological creatures such as dragons and the phoenix were widely used elements in Chinese architecture, as were images of tigers, deer, birds, monkeys, and bears. Different colors were associated with royalty (yellow), the sky (blue), fertility of the earth (black), and good luck (red), and were used to paint wooden structural elements or ceramics such as roof tiles.

Building Materials

Classical Chinese architects used a number of different materials, including wood, ceramics, bricks, marble, bronze, and other materials.

Source of Construction Labor

Rulers of various Chinese dynasties drafted peasants to work on the constant building projects that were ordered to be completed.

content.text:
In the sixth century B.C.E., Kong Fuxi (Confucius) developed a philosophy that had moral, social, and political dimensions. Despite a disappointing career, his teachings developed a following, and those disciples compiled his sayings into a written work known as the Analects. His view of life was entirely practical as he did not deal with religion or abstract philosophy. Rather, he focused on the moral and ethical behavior of the individual.

According to Confucius, there were three important qualities in a superior individual, or junzi, and those qualities were courtesy (ren), propriety (li), and filial piety (xiao). He believed that it was the presence of highly moral citizens that produced an orderly and effective society and government. Confucius encouraged his followers to study classic texts from the Zhou dynasty. The study of those classics, along with others, remained a fixture of Chinese education until the twentieth century.

content.text:
Daoists approached the chaos of the time with a philosophy opposite that of Confucianism. Daoists emphasized a withdrawal from society because they saw no real solution to the problems. Instead, they advocated learning to live in passive harmony with the world. If everyone followed the dao, or "the ways of the cosmos," society would fix itself. The ideal citizen practiced wuwei, or complete withdrawal from the active world, and emphasized pursuit of self-knowledge. Daoists believed that following the natural principles that governed the world, such as diet and meditation, would restore balance and harmony.

The traditional founder of Daoism was a philosopher named Laozi, but historians believe that he is a composite of several different thinkers of the era. Confucians found parts of Daoism very appealing and, since neither philosophy required exclusivity, Chinese scholars often were faithful Confucian bureaucrats as well as devoted followers of Daoism in their private lives.

content.text:
Legalism, a style of governing that relies on strict laws and harsh punishments, unified and calmed China. One of the most famous theorists of Legalism was Han Feizi, who wrote that the only answer to chaos was harsh governance. The basis of an orderly society was the military and agriculture, so Legalists emphasized soldiers and peasants while de-emphasizing other classes. Men were discouraged from becoming merchants or scholars. Harsh penalties were imposed on both minor and major crimes. Entire families could be punished along with the offender.

Emperor Qin Shihuangdi and other rulers used Legalism to unite China in the Qin and Han dynasties. In later dynasties, tension arose between those advocating moral behavior of Confucianism and those promoting rule of law in Legalism. Legalism was effective, but history was written by Confucianists. Thus, Legalists have been harshly criticized in the annals of Chinese history.
